stages.description: Building equal groups of 3 using counters, cubes or Numicon 3-plates, physically counting the total and then dividing groups back
stages.example_activity: Make 4 groups of 3 cubes. Count all: 12. Now take 24 counters and share into groups of 3. How many groups? 8. So 24 ÷ 3 = 8.
stages.transition_cue: Child recalls 3× facts to 12 × 3 without building groups and can state the corresponding division fact

stages.description: Drawing arrays (rows of 3), using a multiplication grid to spot patterns, highlighting multiples of 3 on a hundred square
stages.example_activity: Draw a 7 × 3 array on squared paper. Count all squares: 21. Colour multiples of 3 on a hundred square. What pattern do the digit sums make?
stages.transition_cue: Child uses the digit-sum pattern (multiples of 3 have digit sums that are multiples of 3) to self-check and answers without the grid

stages.description: Instant recall of all 3× multiplication and division facts, applying them in word problems and deriving related facts
stages.example_activity: 3 × 7? 27 ÷ 3? If 3 × 8 = 24, what is 30 × 8? There are 36 children in groups of 3. How many groups?
stages.transition_cue: Child answers any 3× fact within 2 seconds and derives related facts (e.g. 30 × 3, 300 × 3) without hesitation

stages.description: Building equal groups of 4 using counters and Numicon 4-plates, connecting to the doubling of the 2 times table with paired groups
stages.example_activity: Make 6 groups of 2 cubes: total 12. Now double each group to 4 cubes: total 24. So 6 × 4 = double 6 × 2. Divide 32 counters into groups of 4.
stages.transition_cue: Child uses the doubling strategy fluently and recalls 4× facts to 12 × 4 without physical objects

stages.description: Drawing arrays showing the 2× and 4× relationship side by side, using a multiplication grid for 4s facts
stages.example_activity: Draw a 6 × 2 array and a 6 × 4 array side by side. The 4s array is exactly double the 2s array. Record all 4× facts on the multiplication grid.
stages.transition_cue: Child identifies and uses the doubling relationship on paper and answers 4× questions without the grid

stages.description: Instant recall of all 4× multiplication and division facts, deriving related facts and solving word problems
stages.example_activity: 4 × 9? 48 ÷ 4? If 4 × 7 = 28, what is 4 × 70? A pack has 4 biscuits. I buy 8 packs. How many biscuits?
stages.transition_cue: Child answers any 4× fact within 2 seconds and uses halving to divide by 4 (halve, then halve again)

stages.description: Building equal groups of 8 using cubes, demonstrating the doubling chain from 2s to 4s to 8s with physical objects
stages.example_activity: Build 5 groups of 2 cubes: 10. Double each to 4: 20. Double each again to 8: 40. So 5 × 8 = 40. Now divide 64 cubes into groups of 8.
stages.transition_cue: Child applies the double-double-double chain confidently and recalls 8× facts without physical grouping

stages.description: Drawing the 2-4-8 doubling chain on triple number lines, completing a multiplication grid for 8s, highlighting the ones-digit pattern
stages.example_activity: On three parallel number lines, mark jumps of 2, 4 and 8. Draw arrows showing doubling relationships. Notice the 8s ones-digit pattern: 8, 6, 4, 2, 0, 8, 6...
stages.transition_cue: Child answers 8× questions from the grid pattern or doubling strategy, without building or drawing

stages.description: Instant recall of all 8× multiplication and division facts, using halving for division by 8
stages.example_activity: 8 × 7? 72 ÷ 8? If 8 × 6 = 48, what is 80 × 6? Divide 96 by 8: halve (48), halve (24), halve (12). So 96 ÷ 8 = 12.
stages.transition_cue: Child answers any 8× fact within 3 seconds and explains the halving strategy for division

stages.description: Physically demonstrating the doubling chain with cubes: building towers of 2, doubling to 4, doubling again to 8
stages.example_activity: Build 6 towers of 2 red cubes (12). Put 2 blue cubes on each to make towers of 4 (24). Put 4 green cubes on each to make towers of 8 (48). Doubling pattern!
stages.transition_cue: Child explains the doubling connection in words: '4s are double 2s and 8s are double 4s' without needing the cubes

stages.description: Writing the 2, 4 and 8 times tables in parallel columns and drawing doubling arrows, using a bar model to show the relationship
stages.example_activity: Write the 2, 4 and 8 times tables side by side. Draw arrows showing doubling. Use a bar model: 2×6=12, 4×6=24 (double bar), 8×6=48 (double again).
stages.transition_cue: Child uses the doubling relationship to derive any 4× or 8× fact from the 2× table on paper without the three-column chart

stages.description: Using the doubling/halving relationship mentally to derive facts across the 2-4-8 family and to divide efficiently
stages.example_activity: I know 2 × 9 = 18. What is 4 × 9? 8 × 9? To divide 72 by 8: halve three times (72→36→18→9). To divide 48 by 4: halve twice (48→24→12).
stages.transition_cue: Child spontaneously uses the doubling/halving relationship when solving multiplication and division problems

stages.description: Using Dienes blocks and Cuisenaire rods to model 2-digit × 1-digit multiplication as repeated groups, physically partitioning the 2-digit number
stages.example_activity: Calculate 24 × 3. Build 24 three times with Dienes: 3 groups of 2 tens and 4 ones. Combine: 6 tens and 12 ones. Exchange 10 ones for 1 ten: 7 tens and 2 ones = 72.
stages.transition_cue: Child models the partition correctly with blocks and explains: '24 × 3 = 20 × 3 + 4 × 3' before calculating

stages.description: Using the grid (area) method to partition and multiply, drawing arrays to show partial products
stages.example_activity: Draw a grid for 24 × 3: top row split into 20 and 4, side labelled 3. Calculate each cell: 20×3=60, 4×3=12. Add partial products: 60+12=72.
stages.transition_cue: Child completes grid method calculations independently and explains why partial products are added

stages.description: Performing compact short multiplication with carrying, using estimation to check answers
stages.example_activity: Calculate 37 × 4 using short multiplication: 7×4=28 (write 8, carry 2), 3×4=12+2=14. Answer: 148. Check: 37×4 ≈ 40×4 = 160. Plausible.
stages.transition_cue: Child sets up and completes short multiplication independently with correct carrying, estimating before calculating

stages.description: Using physical bar models and comparing groups of objects to represent 'times as many' relationships
stages.example_activity: Jack has 3 marbles. Priya has 4 times as many. Build Jack's bar with 3 cubes. Build Priya's with 4 bars of 3 cubes: 12. Priya has 12 marbles.
stages.transition_cue: Child builds scaling models without prompting and says: 'Four times as many means I multiply by 4'

stages.description: Drawing bar models to represent scaling, with one bar showing the 'one unit' and the other showing the scaled amount
stages.example_activity: Draw a bar for 5 cm. Draw another bar that is 3 times as long. How long is it? Label: 5 × 3 = 15 cm. A ribbon is 4 times as long as a 7 cm ribbon. Draw and calculate.
stages.transition_cue: Child draws and interprets scaling bar models for any 'times as many/much/long' problem without physical manipulatives

stages.description: Solving scaling word problems mentally by identifying the multiplication or division required from the language
stages.example_activity: A sunflower is 3 times as tall as a tulip. The tulip is 12 cm tall. How tall is the sunflower? The sunflower is 45 cm. How many times taller is it than a 9 cm daisy?
stages.transition_cue: Child distinguishes 'times as many' (multiplication) from 'more than' (addition) in word problems without visual aids

stages.description: Using real objects (hats, coats, toy figures) to physically try every combination, laying them out systematically
stages.example_activity: You have 3 hats (red, blue, green) and 4 scarves. Put each hat with each scarf in turn: red+scarf1, red+scarf2... How many outfits? List them all.
stages.transition_cue: Child works systematically through all combinations with physical objects, fixing one item and rotating the other

stages.description: Drawing a systematic table or tree diagram to list all combinations, connecting the count to multiplication
stages.example_activity: Draw a table: hats down the side, scarves across the top. Fill in each combination. Count all cells: 3 × 4 = 12. Draw a tree diagram showing the same combinations.
stages.transition_cue: Child creates a systematic table or tree diagram without prompting and connects the total to multiplication: 'It's rows × columns'

stages.description: Calculating the number of combinations as a multiplication without listing, justifying why multiplication works
stages.example_activity: 3 flavours of ice cream and 5 toppings: how many combinations? 3 × 5 = 15. There are 4 starters and 6 mains. How many different two-course meals? Explain why you multiply.
stages.transition_cue: Child calculates combinations directly by multiplication and explains: 'For each of the first choices, there are that many second choices'
